bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Felipe Ponce Carbonell, November 28, 1952

div1.p: Hench is grateful for Carbonell's help, and requests that no recognition be accorded to Hench for his role in preserving Camp Lazear at this time. Hench does not wish to detract from those being memorialized.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Felipe Ponce Carbonell, November 28, 1952
div1.opener:
November 28, 1952
Dr. Felipe Carbonell
San Lazaro 413
Havana, Cuba
My dear Doctor Carbonell:
div1.p:
I appreciate very greatly your letter of November 22 as it is most reassuring.
I shall arrive at the Hotel Nacional on Sunday, November 30 and will try to
get in touch with you sometime between then and Wednesday.

Regarding your very kind suggestion that my own name be permanently displayed
somewhere at Camp Lazear. I am of course deeply touched and very grateful.
I hope you will understand me if I express the hope that nothing be done about
that now. Perhaps much later. The reason is this. I think that one of the
strongest features of my approach to my Cuban and American friends in relation
to all of this matter has been sincere and complete personal disinterestedness; I
have wanted nothing for myself as I believe you know. What my friends do later
I leave to them, but at no time should anything be done to detract in the smallest
iota from the men we are memorializing and I think for a while we should all con-
centrate on them and on one of the most important by-products of this little venture,
the firm strengthening of Cuban-American relations, especially medical relations.
Nevertheless, let me assure you and Doctor Nogueira (if you talk to him - I will
not mention this to him) that I am indeed most grateful for the thought behind
this suggestion.
div1.closer: Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
